ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Site
Study; The code for each individual study
Notes: e.g., the name of the study in multi-grant collections

ElementDescription: Visit name
Relationship of respondent to individual
Notes: 1 = Biological mom; 2 = Biological dad; 3 = Grandparent; 4 = Special education (sped) teacher; 5 = General education teacher; 6 = Occupational therapist; 7 = Speech and language therapist; 8 = Behavioral therapist; ElementDescription: Form used/assessment name
Notes: e.g., Self-Report, Parent Form, Short Form, Revised Version

ElementDescription: gender of respondent
Your child can accept things not going his/her way.
Your child copes well with failure.
Your child thinks before acting.
Your child works out problems with friends or brothers and sisters on his/her own.
Your child can calm down by himself/herself when excited or "all wound up".
Your child does what he /she is told to do.
Your child is very good at understanding other people's feelings.
Your child controls his/her temper when there is a disagreement.
Your child shares things with others.
Your child is helpful to others.
Your child listens to others points of view.
Your child can give suggestions and opinions without being bossy.
